issue.title: Modularize Chrome code
issue.body: Make `hermes.js`, and `backgroundOptions.js` 'webpackable' libraries. Change other existing scripts to allow this.

issue.title: User Accounts
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
It's impossible to authenticate an API pair request. Through public key injection, it's possible for third parties to decrypt future messages sent to a Hermes user.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Allow users to achieve better security by creating Hermes accounts with 2FA to lock out unauthenticated API pair requests for public key injection.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Single factor authentication through Authy style systems.

- Impossible to authenticate repair of Authy.
- Or impossible to repair social media accounts if Authy keys are lost.

**Additional context**
Hermes should still default to open API pairing to preserve ease of use.

issue.title: Remove HERMES_B
issue.body: Your sent message can be decrypted using their public key and your secret key. Instead of sending the same message twice, just decrypt your sent message with their public key.

issue.title: Remove HERMES_B
issue.body: Your sent message can be decrypted using their public key and your secret key. Instead of sending the same message twice, just decrypt your sent message with their public key.

issue.title: Store secret key encrypted on our "cloud"
issue.body:
Give the user the option to store their encrypted secret key on ~~our servers~~ Chrome sync storage. Anyone would have access to this encrypted key, but it can only be decrypted by users with the original master password.

Requirements:
- [x] #1 done
- [ ] UI for option to do this
- [ ] Use encrypted secret key from ~~our cloud~~ Chrome sync storage in place of disk for everything in #1

issue.title: Options
issue.body:
Extended options page where the user can tweak various options. This can be used in #2 to allow the user to turn off the confirmation dialog.

Requirements:
UI for options
Read/write options to disk
Implement options in Hermes logic

This is possibly a requirement for #1 and #3

issue.title: GroupMe Support
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
My GroupMe isn't encrypted

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Unobtrusive drop-in encryption for GroupMe ala the existing Hermes backend.
Have the option to create encrypted groups (prepend group names with 'HERMES_').
All messages sent in the group will be encrypted with a symmetric group key.
DMs are handled like normal.

- [ ] Crypto
- [ ] Pair ids with API
- [ ] Encrypted group creation UI
- [x] Get ids
- [x] Intercepts
- [x] Render message icons

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
None

**Additional context**
None

issue.title: Add linting using eslint
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
By not linting the current code base there are potential bugs and irregularity in how the code is written. By linting we will ensure the standardization of code style across the project and mitigate bugs related to syntax errors or poor style decisions.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The introduction of linting using [ESLint](https://eslint.org/) with [Airbnb's style guide](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Not linting: it's possible that we could self-enforce a common style guide, but given human error it seems to be a good idea to have a machine check to make sure the style is enforced.
Other linters and style guides: [JSHint](https://jshint.com/), [Prettier](https://prettier.io/), [standard](https://standardjs.com/), [semistandard](https://github.com/Flet/semistandard), [clinton](https://github.com/SamVerschueren/clinton) either lack features or the depth of configuration of ESLint.

The choice of Airbnb's style is based on the similarity to how I naturally write code and their requirement of semicolons where standard and Prettier explicitly disallow semicolons. My own thoughts on the semicolon debate are:
- either choice requires understanding of automatic semicolon insertion (ASI) to avoid edge cases so it cannot be used to advocate one over the other
- either choice, when using a linter, requires no extra cognitive effort to use as the linter catches mistakes
- being explicit without adding extra complexity should be valued over style or aesthetic
- coming from languages that require semicolons means that semicolons carry a familiarity for me
- code should be written to be as accessible to as many as possible and as such be as explicit and unambiguous as possible, JavaScript written with semicolons more explicitly denotes the separation of statements and can be copy-pasted or moved to a different context without issue
If evidence exists against any of these points, most importantly the last one, and it can be shown that no-semicolon provides tangible benefits to semicolon usage I gladly emit semicolons.

issue.body:
Please test options with updateOption(key, value) in the background page console.

> updateOption(key, value)

< true: update in memory and local storage set() requested but not necessarily complete.

< false: option is disabled and was not updated.

issue.title: Better UI prompt for master password
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
UI is default `prompt()` and can be muted through Chrome.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Some sort of UI in the popup that also alerts you if you haven't entered your master password yet and you are in a encrypt-able session.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Continuing to use the existing `prompt()` but still including the alert and error handling for no master password entered.

**Additional context**
Either way, there needs to be some indication that the master password has not been entered, and the secret keys are inaccessible.

issue.title: Store secret key encrypted local
issue.body:
Store key locally encrypted with a master password the user will have to supply or choose to keep stored hashed on disk. This makes it easy to use but effectively is just an additional means of security theater.

Requirements:
UI for choosing master password
If user chooses not to store master password on disk, UI for decryption of secret key
Option to store master password hash on disk along with secret key (yikes but ease of use)
Decryption of secret key with master password hash when secret key is needed
